wikipedia_page.main: Dan Theophilus Beddoe (16 March 1863 – 26 December 1937) was a Welsh tenor, particularly known for his performances in oratorio over a career spanning 50 years.

response: Born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Beddoe was the son of Dan Beddoe, a Welsh classical singer,  and his wife Mary. He graduated from the University of Cincinnati with bachelor's and master's degrees and taught English for three years.
*Tenors: Edward Lloyd, Ben Davies, Dan Beddoe, Evan Williams

Edna de Lima first sang at New York's Aeolian Hall in 1916."Edna de Lima's Recital" New York Times (October 24, 1916): 13. via ProQuest She made her Chicago concert debut in 1917, when a reviewer declared that "Nature has been bounteous to Mme. de Lima in the bestowal of personal attractiveness and grace of manner in addition to the crystalline purity of her voice.""Edna de Lima in Recital" Music News (March 23, 1917): 18. She was billed as "formerly of the Vienna Opera" when she appeared at the Stadium Concerts in New York in the summer of 1918."Edna de Lima at the Stadium" Musical Courier (July 25, 1918): 39. She performed on a bill with pianist Winifred Byrd, tenor Dan Beddoe, and violinist Michel Gusikoff, for the Globe Music Club later in 1918."Globe Music Club" Musical Courier (October 24, 1918): 8. She translated lyrics for recitalists, including Margaret Matzenauer. During World War I, she sang at concerts for the Liberty Bond Campaign,"Edna de Lima, a Many-Sided Artist" Musical Courier (October 10, 1918): 47. and for the Red Cross."Bass Clef Concert for Red Cross" Norwich Bulletin (May 20, 1918): 10. via Newspapers.com
